title: BUG: inconsistency between prepared and unprepared polygon contains predicate · Issue #740 · libgeos/geos

last_post.content:
GEOS is pretty darn robust, but there's an interesting class of failures that are the root of more than one of the extant issues.

When evaluating predicates (true/false tests on geometry relationships) and full DE9IM relationships, JTS/GEOS will perform noding on the inputs before evaluating the relationship between them.

This results in a sort of "heisenberg uncertainty principle" of geometry predicates. The act of evaluating them changes them slightly.

https://github.com/libgeos/geos/issues/740#issuecomment-1325776721

title: GitHub - FahimF/FediJS: A pure JavaScript Fediverse client

last_post.content:
I did some more work on my JavaScript Fedi client over the weekend:

https://github.com/FahimF/FediJS

I’m not progressing as fast as I had done with other Masto/Fedi clients in the past in terms of adding features, and yet, it’s so much easier (at least so far) to add new features for the JavaScript client 🙂

Now, I’m by no means a JavaScript guru. Sure, I’ve been using JavaScript since the early days of the web, but only as needed. It has never been one of my main programming languages. So I find it interesting that I can do a lot more with a lot less code in this particular instance.

I added the ability to boost, favourite, and bookmark posts in the timeline with relatively little effort.

I’m thinking of adding hashtag and lists support next weekend possibly. I guess we’ll see how it goes …

last_post.content:
Introducing {deft} - code for creating data.frames within C and returning to user.

Benchmarks show creating totally within C can be *FAST*!

~100x faster than creating data.frames with tibble() or data.frame()

https://github.com/coolbutuseless/deft

This is designed to be used as a 'LinkingTo' package, so that I can use these functions as part of a bigger project.

#RStats

title: GitHub - coolbutuseless/deftly: Demonstration of using the C data.frame functions in the {deft} package.

last_post.content:
And I only figured out today how to properly(?) call C code from one package in another package.

So I wrote {deftly} package as a reminder to myself how this works with:

* Set LinkingTo: deft
* Set Depends: deft
* #include <deft.h>

And how to write a correct deft.h and exporting of C callables from {deft}'s init.c

All this came from studying how {systemfonts} package works.

{deftly} just imports and calls the C code from {deft}

https://github.com/coolbutuseless/deftly

#ReleaseThursday This is actually the 2nd bunch of #ThingUmbrella releases since the weekend (which I completely forgot to notify about). The main highlights are:

https://thi.ng/color - added #Oklch support, update #Oklab conversion matrices (to latest spec), updated/improved/fixed CSS color parsing & serializations (more input formats, wider support for using percentages in more places), added serialization options for CSS Color Module Level 4, more docs

https://thi.ng/hiccup-markdown - major new version w/ completely new & extensible parser to transform #Markdown (with custom extensions[1]) into a proper abstract syntax tree and then transform elements via user defined handlers into arbitrary data structures. The default handlers generate a https://thi.ng/hiccup tree. More info in the package readme and the readme of this interactive parser & live preview demo: https://demo.thi.ng/umbrella/markdown/

[1] The syntax extensions include blocks of arbitrary metadata attached to _any_ blocklevel element (e.g. headings, paragraphs, tables, lists etc.) and custom typed blocks of content

As usual, please see changelogs for other updates:

https://github.com/thi-ng/umbrella/blob/develop/README.md#latest-updates

Happy Coding! 😍​

title: Release Whisper and GCP Compute Runners · CouncilDataProject/cookiecutter-cdp-deployment

last_post.content:
@MattHodges we just released v4 of Council Data Project which uses Whisper for transcripts too!

https://github.com/CouncilDataProject/cookiecutter-cdp-deployment/releases/tag/v4.0.0

It uses GitHub actions to spin up a GCP compute engine instance, processes the events, and then tears down the instance. GitHub Actions keeps the logs and makes it easier for users to trigger their own runs as well as CRON.

It's incredibly incredibly cheap.
